title: Astronomers carry out largest ever cosmological computer simulation
description: An international team of astronomers has carried out what is believed to be the largest ever cosmological computer simulation, tracking not only dark but also ordinary matter (such as planets, stars and galaxies), giving us a glimpse into how our universe may have evolved.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Buzz, Elsa or Gru: Is there a role for pain and violence in children's media?
description: Whether it's the antics of Tom and Jerry or a boo-boo on Peppa Pig, pain and violence have long been portrayed in children's TV and movies. But how suitable is such content in children's broadcasting?
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Study finds mindfulness training may not be enough to increase eco-friendliness
description: Could general well-being practices like meditation encourage eco-friendly behaviors and attitudes? As the climate crisis accelerates ecological disasters around the world, scientists' investigations into this longstanding question have taken on greater urgency. A study from the Center for Healthy Minds at the University of Wisconsin–Madison explores the connection between meditation and environmental consciousness and suggests the relationship might not be that simple.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Residents unprepared for wildland fires, face barriers in implementing prevention measures: Study
description: This year, Canada saw the worst wildfire season in its history, with fires destroying homes, displacing thousands of residents, and burning the largest area since contemporary records began in 1983. Much of this damage to communities could be reduced with better wildfire preparedness—but wildland urban interface (WUI) communities often face significant barriers in implementing these improvements, according to a study by York University's Disaster and Emergency Management researchers.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: UK screen industry failing to tackle sexual harassment, according to new report
description: The UK film and screen industry is failing to tackle sexual harassment, with some victims punished or victimized if they do speak out, according to a new report looking at the experiences of staff in a range of roles across the television and film industry.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Apoptotic cells may drive cell death in hair follicles during regression cycle
description: A new research paper titled "Apoptotic cells may drive cell death in hair follicles during their regression cycle" has been published in Oncotarget.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: First confirmed cases of avian influenza in the Antarctic region
description: Highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) has been confirmed in brown skua populations on Bird Island, South Georgia—the first known cases in the Antarctic region.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Veterinarians use little devices to make giant impact on cat's life
description: "James Dean," a dapper orange tabby cat, lives a star-studded life. He fills his days playing mischievously with his sister, "Audrey Hepburn," and his brother, "Elvis," while his nights are spent snuggled up with his owners, Kaci and Melvin Thomas, who live in Austin.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Female board members help improve firms' corporate sustainability reporting, finds study
description: New research has revealed that firms with female directors on the board, regardless of how many, improves the quality of corporate sustainability disclosures than those with no board representation.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Multifactorial stress in citrus: Divergent responses of Carrizo and Cleopatra to triple threat environmental challenges
description: Climate change, alongside human-induced adverse factors, threatens agricultural production and food security by causing stressful situations for plants, such as increased temperatures, extreme weather events, pest outbreaks, diseases, and pollution.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Microbial allies may help turn tables on tar spot fungus in corn
description: Agricultural Research Service (ARS) scientists are leaving no stone—or rather, leaf—unturned in their search for new ways to counter the fungus that causes tar spot, a yield-robbing disease of field corn in the midwestern United States.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: People who communicate more, show expertise are more likely to be seen as essential team members: Study
description: A new study sheds light on the vital role of communication and expertise within organizations, revealing their impact on group performance. Researchers examined how individuals become part of communication networks and the effect of selection processes on group performance.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Genetic analysis: Dutch bluetongue virus type is unique
description: The bluetongue virus is rapidly spreading in the Netherlands. With the use of new techniques, including whole genome sequencing, it has quickly become clear that the Dutch virus is a different virus variant in comparison to previous outbreaks.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Equality in the labor market needs more than public childcare, economists say
description: Having children poses serious financial challenges. One researcher to demonstrate this is U.S. economist Claudia Goldin, who was awarded this year's Nobel Prize in Economic Sciences for her research on gender differences in the labor market.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Q&A: Do we need a new approach to prevent bird window strikes?
description: In early October, nearly 1,000 birds perished after colliding with the windows of a convention center near Lake Michigan in Chicago, marking the largest mass bird die-off in decades. But bird window-strike fatalities are an ongoing threat. Illinois Natural History Survey wildlife ecologist Thomas J. Benson, an expert in bird population trends in Illinois, spoke to News Bureau life sciences editor Diana Yates about the problem and what new strategies may help.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Access to creative higher education remains highly unequal, says new UK report
description: A new report has found that the creative workforce is still dominated by graduates, with access to creative higher education remaining highly unequal.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Research finds racial disparity in school closures
description: Each year about 2% of U.S. public schools permanently close their doors, a trend that has translated in recent years to roughly 1,000 school closures annually. Budgetary constraints or low academic performance are typically cited as justification, but advocates have argued that these decisions unfairly target communities of color, particularly schools with large shares of Black students.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: A solar 'radio eclipse' ring of fire
description: On October 14, as most Californians were treated to a partial solar eclipse, researchers at the Owens Valley Radio Observatory (OVRO) took in a different view.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: An unusual crater on Pluto might be a supervolcano
description: Pluto with a super-cryovolcano? Why not! All the elements are there, just not in the way we normally think of volcanoes. And cryovolcanoes are the reason why Pluto's surface looks the way it does. A recent research paper explains why Pluto could be the home of the latest supervolcano discovery in the solar system.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: JWST looks at the debris disk around a white dwarf
description: Debris disks are quite common in the universe. Young stars have protoplanetary disks from which planets form. Black holes have accretion disks that are the source of the galactic jets. Supernova remnants can form a disk around neutron stars. So what about white dwarfs?
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Genomic stability: A double-edged sword for sharks
description: Sharks have been populating the oceans for about 400 to 500 million years. While our planet and many of its inhabitants have undergone massive changes several times during this period, this basal group of vertebrates has remained somewhat constant. Their body shape and biology has hardly changed since then.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: New study shows surprising effects of fire in North America's boreal forests
description: A new study, using a first-of-its-kind approach to analyze satellite imagery from boreal forests over the last three decades, has found that fire may be changing the face of the region in a way researchers did not previously anticipate.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: LIGO surpasses the quantum limit
description: In 2015, the Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory (LIGO), made history when it made the first direct detection of gravitational waves—ripples in space and time—produced by a pair of colliding black holes.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: In 1952, a group of three 'stars' vanished—astronomers still can't find them
description: On July 19, 1952, Palomar Observatory was undertaking a photographic survey of the night sky. Part of the project was to take multiple images of the same region of sky, to help identify things such as asteroids. At around 8:52 that evening a photographic plate captured the light of three stars clustered together. At a magnitude of 15, they were reasonably bright in the image. At 9:45 pm the same region of sky was captured again, but this time the three stars were nowhere to be seen. In less than an hour they had completely vanished.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Skin and gut microbiome analysis offers new therapeutic perspectives on atopic dermatitis in Shiba Inu dogs
description: Complex diseases—including cancer, metabolic diseases and allergies—affect not only humans, but also domestic animals, such as dogs. Approximately 10% of the dog population suffers from canine atopic dermatitis (cAD). This well-known common disease in dogs is characterized by excessive pruritis (itchiness) and is caused by allergy to environmental allergens, such as pollens and mites.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Researchers discover genes responsible for low and ultra-low glycemic index in rice
description: The International Rice Research Institute (IRRI) announced they achieved a scientific milestone with the discovery of the genes responsible for low and ultra-low glycemic index (GI) in rice.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: More heat waves and vanishing snow: The lake Tahoe basin's future on a warming planet
description: Lake Tahoe is known for its crystal-clear blue water, scenic mountain backdrop, and world-class recreation opportunities. Unfortunately, the lake and surrounding basin aren't insulated from global climate change.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Study discovers ferns can produce crop-saving insecticide
description: A new study has identified novel insecticidal proteins in ferns. Professor Marilyn Anderson at La Trobe University said the discovery could lead to plant-made protein pest control for crop plants that are essential to global food production.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Young Australians increasingly get news from social media, but many don't understand algorithms
description: Adults might assume young people are not engaged in current affairs.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Hera asteroid mission goes on trial
description: At some point, statistically speaking, a large asteroid will impact Earth. Whether that's tomorrow, in 10 years, or a problem for our ancestors, ESA is getting prepared.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: A layered lake reveals how oxygen built up in our atmosphere billions of years ago
description: Little Deming Lake doesn't get much notice from visitors to Itasca State Park in Minnesota. There's better boating on nearby Lake Itasca, the headwaters of the Mississippi River. My colleagues and I need to maneuver hundreds of pounds of equipment down a hidden path made narrow by late-summer poison ivy to launch our rowboats.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: How to watch October's Orionids meteor shower and contemplate the wonders of the sky
description: Throughout the year, there are different meteor showers that all have different properties and can be more or less easy to spot.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Storm Babet caused dangerous floods as the 'dry side' of Scotland isn't used to such torrential rain
description: Storm Babet has caused havoc across the UK, with strong winds and rough seas along the east coast, record breaking rainfall and river levels in Scotland, overtopped flood defenses, closed roads and railways and sadly at least two deaths. The impacts are not over as further rain is expected.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: What happens to switchgrass when food reserves are depleted?
description: As potential for biofuel, switchgrass is a perennial plant that is of great interest to researchers. Scientists from the MSU-DOE Plant Research Laboratory Walker lab are looking at how these plants regrow, even when regrowing with less than its usual carbon storage.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Students with strong self-belief are happier and more successful, research finds
description: Students' success and happiness can be improved by building their self-belief—their perception of their capacity to complete a challenging task.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: New research helps explain why Indian girls appear to be less engaged in politics than Indian boys
description: Girls in India report being less interested and engaged in politics than boys and cite fewer opportunities to participate in politics, we found in a recent survey of youth across India.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Researchers: Here's what happens to workers when coal-fired power plants in Australia close. It isn't good
description: When Australia's dirtiest coal-fired power plant, Hazelwood in Victoria, closed in 2017, Australian authorities were blind to the collateral damage.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: EPA is funding more community air-pollution monitoring in Colorado, but nonprofits struggle to roll it out
description: The Black Parents United Foundation learned in late 2022 that it would receive nearly $475,000 from the Environmental Protection Agency to set up air monitors in Aurora to determine how much pollution residents in low-income neighborhoods were breathing.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Video: An antidote for deadly mushrooms?
description: Almost all mushroom-related fatalities worldwide are caused by a single group of molecules, cyclopeptides, which are found in death caps and destroying angels.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: The effects of mass layoffs on a brand and the role of corporate communication
description: Especially in times of economic crisis, companies frequently lay off employees. In the short term, this can reduce costs—but what consequences does this measure have for a company's brand? A new study by researchers from KLU, Tilburg University and KU Leuven has investigated the phenomenon and provides clear recommendations on how communication measures should be planned.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: JcSEUSS1 shown to play negative role in regulating reproductive growth of Jatropha curcas
description: In Arabidopsis, rice and tomato, the SEUSS gene encodes a transcriptional adaptor as well as a nuclear localization protein that is widely expressed in many developmental stages and organs. However, the function of SEUSS has not been reported in woody plants.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Hubble captures spiral galaxy IC 5332 face-on
description: This glittering image from the NASA/ESA Hubble Space Telescope shows the spiral galaxy IC 5332. The galaxy lies about 30 million light-years away in the constellation Sculptor and has an almost face-on orientation to Earth. To understand the term "face-on," it is helpful to visualize a spiral galaxy as an extremely large disk. If the galaxy's orientation makes it appear circular and disk-shaped from our perspective on Earth, then we say that it is "face-on."
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Carl Sagan detected life on Earth 30 years ago—here's how his experiment is helping us search for alien species today
description: It's been 30 years since a group of scientists led by Carl Sagan found evidence for life on Earth using data from instruments on board the Nasa Galileo robotic spacecraft. Yes, you read that correctly. Among his many pearls of wisdom, Sagan was famous for saying that science is more than a body of knowledge—it is a way of thinking.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: A high-quality Bougainvillea genome helps to explore evolutionary history of a pigment biosynthetic pathway
description: Bougainvillea, a widely appreciated ornamental shrub, originates from South America and stands out due to its vibrant bract colors, which are believed to result from betalain accumulation. Although Bougainvillea has important ornamental and prophylactic value, the lack of genomic data has limited in-depth understanding of bract coloration and breeding pathways, and the relationship between betalain accumulation and Bougainvillea phenotypes had not yet been fully understood.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Every letter counts: New research on New Mexican Spanish pronunciation
description: Me-muh-ry or mem-ry (memory), fa-muh-ly or fam-ly (family), ce-luh-ry or cel-ry (celery), and so on—there are different ways to pronounce words. Across languages, linguists spend a lot of time figuring out what it is about the way that we use language that predicts when speakers produce certain words.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Washington's volcanoes are experiencing seismic tremors from an unlikely source—glaciers
description: Most people think of seismic activity as the result of movement along faults or of violent volcanic eruptions. But seismic events can have other causes, including floods and even large crowds of excited fans—such as those at Taylor Swift's recent Seattle shows, whose enthusiastic reception caused seismic activity equivalent to a 2.3 magnitude earthquake—and glaciers.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Do red dwarfs or sunlike stars have more Earth-sized worlds?
description: Earth is our only example of a habitable planet, so it makes sense to search for Earth-size worlds when we're hunting for potentially-habitable exoplanets. When astronomers found seven of them orbiting a red dwarf star in the TRAPPIST-1 system, people wondered if Earth-size planets are more common around red dwarfs than sun-like stars.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: A Russian satellite has shifted within 60 km of another spacecraft
description: When it comes to saber-rattling, few countries employ it as much as Russia does. During their ongoing invasion and occupation of Ukraine, the country's leadership has repeatedly threatened to use atomic weapons. But the threats don't stop there.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Working towards programmable matter: Unexpected behavior discovered in active particles
description: Investigating systems consisting of self-propelled particles—so-called active particles—is a rapidly growing area of research. In theoretical models for active particles, it is often assumed that the particles' swimming speed is always the same. This is not so, however, for particles produced in many experiments, for example for those propelled by ultrasound for medical applications. In these cases, the propulsion speed depends on the orientation.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: New exoplanet-informed research sets clearer bounds on the search for radio technosignatures
description: In a new study published in The Astronomical Journal, researchers used the known population of exoplanets and extrapolated to the much larger, unknown population of exoplanets to set better thresholds for planetary effects on signals from ETIs (extraterrestrial intelligences).
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Using DNA metabarcoding to analyze soil organism composition change in crop rotation farmland
description: A research team led by Professor Toshihiko Eki of the Department of Applied Chemistry and Life Science, Toyohashi University of Technology and others used DNA metabarcoding to analyze changes in the composition of soil organisms associated with crop growth in two corn-cabbage rotation fields in Tahara City.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Climate change is increasing risk of high toxin concentrations in northern US lakes, study finds
description: As climate change warms the Earth, higher-latitude regions will be at greater risk for toxins produced by algal blooms, according to new research led by Carnegie's Anna Michalak, Julian Merder, and Gang Zhao. Their findings, published in Nature Water, identify water temperatures of 20 to 25 degrees Celsius (68 to 77 degrees Fahrenheit) as being at the greatest risk for developing dangerous levels of a common algae-produced toxin called microcystin.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: How could a piece of the moon become a near-Earth asteroid? Researchers have an answer
description: A team of astronomers has found a new clue that a recently discovered near-Earth asteroid, Kamo'oalewa, might be a chunk of the moon. They hypothesized that the asteroid was ejected from the lunar surface during a meteorite strike—and they found that a rare pathway could have allowed Kamo'oalewa to get into orbit around the sun while remaining close to the orbits of the Earth and the moon.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Scientists create artificial protein capable of degrading microplastics in bottles
description: Every year, around 400 million tons of plastics are produced worldwide, a number that increases by around 4% annually. The emissions resulting from their manufacture are one of the elements contributing to climate change, and their ubiquitous presence in ecosystems leads to serious ecological problems.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Researchers correct overestimation by 'hot model' climate projections on warming in China
description: Changes in mean temperature and temperature extremes at regional scale under a warmer climate have received much attention. A subset of CMIP6 climate models, known as "hot models," have been projecting more significant warming due to greenhouse gases.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: How ready is your town? Researchers help coastal towns prepare for the next storm in a changing climate
description: Hurricane Sandy brought devastation to the East Coast on October 29, 2012. With the destabilizing effects of the climate crisis, coupled with sea level rise, these record-breaking disasters are quickly becoming normal occurrences. Communities need to build resilience quickly, and UConn researchers are working on a metric to help coastal areas prioritize which measures to focus on. Their research is published in the International Journal of Disaster Risk Reduction.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Scientists engineer plants to speak in color as environmental sensors for dangerous chemicals
description: What if your house plant could tell you your water isn't safe? Scientists are closer to realizing this vision, having successfully engineered a plant to turn beet red in the presence of a banned, toxic pesticide.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Who were the first modern humans to settle in Europe?
description: Before modern humans settled definitively in Europe, other human populations left Africa for Europe beginning approximately 60,000 years ago, albeit without settling for the long term. This was due to a major climatic crisis 40,000 years ago, combined with a super-eruption originating from the Phlegraean Fields volcanic area near current-day Naples, subsequently precipitating a decline in ancient European populations.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Researchers propose new strategy to improve efficiency for nanotherapeutic delivery in tumors
description: A team led by Prof. Wang Yucai and Associate Prof. Jiang Wei from the University of Science and Technology of China (USTC) of the Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS) revealed the mechanism of the tumor vascular basement membranes (BM) blocking nanoparticles (NPs) for the first time and developed an immunodriven strategy to increase the NP penetration through the BM barrier. Their work was published in Nature Nanotechnology.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Ancient pots hold clues about how diverse diets helped herders thrive in southern Africa
description: The introduction of herding—a way of life which centers on keeping herds of mobile domesticated animals—significantly changed Africa's genetic, economic, social and cultural landscapes during the last 10,000 years. Unlike other parts of the world, mobile herding spread throughout the continent thousands of years before farming and did not replace foraging in many places. This gave rise to complex mosaics of foragers and food producers across sub-Saharan Africa.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Incorporating nature into education can build skills and improve mental health
description: Could carving a wooden spoon by a lake be the answer to the mental health crisis in Canadian universities and also global sustainability?
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Q&A: A new Nobel laureate describes the development of quantum dots from basic research to industry application
description: The Nobel Prize in chemistry for 2023 goes to three scientists "for the discovery and synthesis of quantum dots." The Conversation Weekly podcast caught up with one of this trio, physical chemist Louis Brus, who did foundational work figuring out that the properties of these nanoparticles depend on their size. Brus' phone was off when the Nobel reps called to inform him of the good news, but now plenty of people have gotten through with congratulations and advice. Below are edited excerpts from the podcast.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Unveiling the potential of soybeans for enhanced nutrition
description: In a study published in the Journal of Integrative Agriculture, researchers from the Chinese Academy of Agricultural Sciences conducted an in-depth analysis of over 1,000 diverse soybean accessions from China, honing in on the levels of beneficial carotenoids.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: New climate maps predict major changes in vegetation by end of century
description: A multinational study seen in Scientific Data and led by KAUST reports that the global climate has experienced notable changes in climate classification over the past century, and these shifts are projected to intensify in the coming decades. With an updated version of the 1-km Kӧppen-Geiger climate classification maps released in 2018, the study provides a comprehensive view of historical and future climate conditions across the globe.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: How secrecy and regulatory capture drove Alberta's oil and gas liability crisis
description: "A hustle in the oil patch", a "dirty legacy": These are just a couple of the ways that the escalating costs of abandoning and reclaiming non-producing oil wells in Canada have been described.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: 'Digital inclusion' and closing the gap: How First Nations leadership is key to getting remote communities online
description: There are more than 1,500 remote First Nations communities and homelands around Australia, and about 670 of them have no mobile phone coverage. In research with 495 people from ten remote communities, we found 45.9% were "highly excluded" from increasingly important digital services and tools.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: From meerkat school to whale-tail slapping and oyster smashing, how clever predators shape their world
description: In the 1980s a single humpback whale in the Gulf of Maine developed the "lobtail feeding method." This unique hunting method of slapping the water's surface appears to drive fish into dense schools, making it easier to consume them. Lobtail feeding caught on. Now many humpback whales are doing it.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Cleaning up Australia's 80,000 disused mines is a huge job—but the payoffs can outweigh the costs
description: Newly announced closures of Glencore's copper and zinc mines in Mt Isa will add to a huge number of former mines in Australia. A 2020 study by Monash University's Resources Trinity Group found more than 80,000 inactive mine sites across the country.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Fungal evolution discovered: Mycena can now invade living hosts
description: Biologists have long known mushrooms of the genus Mycena, commonly known as bonnet mushrooms, as fungi that live off of dead trees and plants. New research from the University of Copenhagen demonstrates that bonnets can also find their ways into young, healthy trees and plants, where they try to cooperate. In doing so, they have made an evolutionary leap which challenges our understanding of the ecological roles of fungi.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Chemists, engineers craft adjustable arrays of microscopic lenses
description: They number in the thousands, light striking the phalanx of lenses arrayed on a face in geometric pattern, the beams refracting through transparent mounds no wider than a hair.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Two groups look at the economic viability of mining asteroids
description: Two teams of economists have conducted economic assessments of mining asteroids—one of them is a trio with one member each from the University of Tor Rome Vergata, the University of Maryland and Middlebury College. They looked at asteroid mining as part of the next logical step in monetizing space exploration.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Biodiversity can rebound after bushfires, but recovery lags in severely burnt areas
description: Extreme fires drove biodiversity declines despite overall resilience after the 2019–2020 Black Summer bushfire season in NSW, a new study suggests.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Increased West Antarctic ice sheet melting 'unavoidable,' say scientists
description: Scientists ran simulations on the UK's national supercomputer to investigate ocean-driven melting of the West Antarctic ice sheet: how much is unavoidable and must be adapted to, and how much melting the international community still has control over through reduction of greenhouse gas emissions.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Mouse mummies point to mammalian life in 'Mars-like' Andes
description: The dry, wind-swept summits of volcanoes in the Puna de Atacama of Chile and Argentina are the closest thing on Earth to the surface of Mars due to their thin atmosphere and freezing temperatures. At their extreme elevations of more than 6,000 meters above sea level, experts had concluded that mammalian life simply wasn't possible. But researchers reporting October 23 in the journal Current Biology on their discovery of mummified mice in those tough environs now expand the physiologic limits of vertebrate life on Earth.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Researchers develop new mechanism to create water-repellent surfaces
description: Researchers have developed a new mechanism to make water droplets slip off surfaces, and describe it in a paper published in Nature Chemistry. The discovery challenges existing ideas about friction between solid surfaces and water and opens up a new avenue for studying droplet slipperiness at the molecular level. The new technique has applications in a range of fields, including plumbing, optics, and the auto and maritime industries.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Researchers trace a powerful radio signal to the most distant source yet—a galaxy billions of lightyears away
description: Every day and night, hundreds of thousands of intense, brief flashes of radiation suddenly flicker on and then off all across the sky. These "fast radio bursts" are invisible to the naked eye, but to a radio telescope many almost outshine everything else in the sky for a few thousandths of a second.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: New lab-made substance mimics human tissue and could reduce/replace the use of animal-derived materials in research
description: Scientists at UNSW Sydney have created a new material that could change the way human tissue can be grown in the lab and used in medical procedures.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Researchers develop DANGER analysis tool for the safer design of gene editing
description: A team of researchers has developed a software tool called DANGER (Deleterious and ANticipatable Guides Evaluated by RNA-sequencing) analysis that provides a way for the safer design of genome editing in all organisms with a transcriptome.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Just add salt: Researcher discovers a safe, simple way to make disinfectants work better
description: A chemical engineer at the University of Alberta has developed a disinfectant that is more effective than purely alcohol-based products, just by adding salt.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Businesses must embrace new ways of thinking or risk missing climate targets, says study
description: Businesses must adopt new ways of thinking to effectively reduce their carbon footprint, suggests a new study from Imperial College Business School.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Iron in ancient deep magma ocean probed by ultra-fast femtosecond X-ray lasers
description: When the Earth was completing its formation approximately 4.5 billion years ago, it was enveloped in a global ocean of molten magma, extending hundreds to thousands of kilometers beneath its surface due to violent impacts. This early environment bore little resemblance to the habitable conditions we experience on Earth today.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Novel platform characterizes both individual carrier and cargo for clinically important molecules
description: Akin to the packages sent from one person to another via an elaborate postal system, cells send tiny parcels that bear contents and packaging material that serve key purposes: To protect the contents from the outside world and to make sure it gets to the right place via a label with an address.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Researchers study fast-moving black hole to better understand formation of black hole binaries
description: UMass Dartmouth Ph.D. students Tousif Islam (lead author) and Feroz H. Shaik, alongside Assistant Professor Vijay Varma and Associate Professor Scott Field (mathematics), recently published findings, on the pre-print server arXiv, that include the identification of a binary black hole system that was most likely formed through dynamical capture and whose collision produced the second fastest-moving black hole observed (denoted GW191109 by astronomers).
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: New technology could lead to quick, minimally invasive cancer diagnoses
description: A new device created at the University of Notre Dame employs an innovative method for "listening in" on cells' conversations.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Scientists amplify superconducting sensor array signals near the quantum limit
description: Understanding how energy moves in materials is fundamental to the study of quantum phenomena, catalytic reactions, and complex proteins. Measuring how energy moves involves shining special X-ray light onto a sample to start a reaction.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Exploring the potential and applications of superhydrophobic surfaces
description: Researchers led by Prof. Zhang Junping from the Lanzhou Institute of Chemical Physics of the Chinese Academy of Sciences have discussed the challenges and strategies for commercialization and widespread practical applications of superhydrophobic surfaces.  The review article was published in Science Advances on Oct. 20.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: 3D-printed hairs: Professor developing tiny sensors to detect flow and environmental changes
description: Eyelashes and brows catch dust and debris from entering eyes. The same idea goes for tiny nose and ear hairs. At a more microscopic level, the tiny hair-like cilia that line human cells help detect subtle environmental changes and can boost a person's senses.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Harnessing heat-induced floral overexpression using CRISPR techniques
description: Plant migration and gene flow from genetically modified or invasive plant species to wild relatives is a major public and regulatory concern. To counteract potential spread, various strategies have been developed, ranging from identifying naturally sterile plants to engineered sterility via gene editing.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: The moon is 40 million years older than thought, lunar crystals study suggests
description: More than 4 billion years ago, when the solar system was still young and the Earth was still growing, a giant object the size of Mars crashed into the Earth. The biggest piece that broke off of the early Earth formed our moon. But precisely when this happened has remained a mystery.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Finding Argoland: How a lost continent resurfaced
description: Geologists have long known that around 155 million years ago, a 5,000 km long piece of continent broke off western Australia and drifted away. They can see that by the 'void' it left behind: a basin hidden deep below the ocean known as the Argo Abyssal Plain. The underwater feature also lends its name to the newly formed continent: Argoland. The structure of the seafloor shows that this continent must have drifted off to the northwest, and must have ended up where the islands of Southeast Asia are located today.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Scientists uncover the role of the muscular and lacunar systems in the externa of parasitic crustaceans
description: Zoologists from St Petersburg University have investigated the muscular and lacunar systems of the externa of rhizocephalan barnacles (Cirripedia: Rhizocephala)—a group of parasitic crustaceans. The paper is published in the Journal of Morphology.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Two Neptune-sized exoplanets discovered with TESS
description: An international team of astronomers reports the detection of two new exoplanets orbiting a bright star known as TOI-5126, using NASA's Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite (TESS). The newfound alien worlds are similar in size to the solar system's outermost planet. The finding was published October 13 on the pre-print server arXiv.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Decline of rare right whale appears to be slowing, but scientists say big threats remain
description: The decline of one of the rarest whales in the world appears to be slowing, but scientists warn the giant mammals still face existential threats from warming oceans, ship collisions and entanglement in fishing gear.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Q&A: Developing a tool to identify cancerous cells from their membranes
description: Dr. Basudev Roy, Associate Professor in the Department of Physics at the Indian Institute of Technology, Madras, has recently published a paper about cell membrane fluctuations and their use for diagnosing cancerous diseases in the journal Physical Biology.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Scientists demonstrate the transport of light cargo using tethered and untethered soft robots made from hydrogels
description: A team of University of Waterloo researchers has created smart, advanced materials that will be the building blocks for a future generation of soft medical microrobots. They published their results in Nature Communications.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Do people everywhere care less about their cats than their dogs?
description: Do canines get more care? Some studies have suggested pet owners are less emotionally attached to and less willing to finance care for cats than dogs, possibly because of cats' behavior: cats may be perceived as caring less about humans and needing less care in return. But these studies are often conducted on non-representative samples and don't consider possible cultural differences in attitudes to pets. A team of scientists led by Dr. Peter Sandøe of the University of Copenhagen decided to investigate further.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Washington still suffers from drought despite rain—and El Nino won't help
description: Despite recent rainfall most of Washington still suffers from drought and climatologists say the months ahead aren't likely to offer much relief.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Pacific footballfish makes rare appearance on Orange County beach
description: For the second time in three years, a rare and otherworldly looking black anglerfish was found at Newport Beach's Crystal Cove State Park, showing up on Friday the 13th with its gaping mouth, jagged, translucent teeth and spiny dorsal fin.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Under a temporary mining ban, four rare plant species can bloom in San Bernardino forest
description: Four threatened and endangered plant species growing in the San Bernardino National Forest will have an opportunity to thrive following the adoption of a plan by the U.S. Bureau of Land Management and U.S. Forest Service that temporarily bans new limestone mining.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: Keep or cull? Romania divided over its bear population
description: It was a sight that stopped traffic. A brown bear seemingly asleep, its head on its paws, on a winding forest road in central Romania, some paper napkins by its side.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories

title: University of Michigan slithers toward history with massive acquisition of jarred snake specimens
description: Greg Schneider scans rows upon rows of liquid-filled glass jars containing coiled snake specimens, just a portion of the University of Michigan Museum of Zoology's reptile and amphibian collection believed to be the largest held by any research institution in the U.S. thanks to a recent donation.
artist: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
album: Phys.org - latest science and technology news stories
